ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic understandings of demography and population trends including why and how certain populations increase/decline over time and what factors contribute.
Better understanding of what sociology and demography are. Also a better understanding of the world and why our society functions as it does in general.
Deeper understanding of various population trends (eg. migration, age, family)
I gained a new understanding of demographic methods and general history of the demographic transition
I learned a lot about statistics. I developed my Microsoft Excel skills while learning data analysis.
Knowledge about demographic shifts, how to write a college literature review, how to work on a group project in a virtual for,at

A very wide and deep understanding of immigration, fertility, mortality, demographic transition, economic transition, urbanity, and much more. The course was eye opening to say the least and was very well-taught.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There was a lot of content which was interesting but meant that the exams cover a lot; considering there was only 50 minutes for each exam and the structure was not exactly clear the first time, it was very difficult to figure out what to actually be prepared for/know in depth and what to move past.

The material of this course was very interesting. In terms of the reading, it didn't make sense to have us read so many calculation formulas in the textbook that we would never apply or be tested on (with the exception of very few). Additionally, the Final Research Project for this course did not compliment what we were learning.

A great weakness is the textbook. It expresses many racist (especially Orientalist), classist, and U.S.-centric positions. On the other hand, the class itself is not so much like that, and I appreciate how we were allowed to integrate our understanding of those problems into our discussions, but the textbook is really a poor choice that doesn't reflect the class environment.
Discussion Section is very engaging and insightful. Lecture is interactive, which is conducive to learning
This course sometimes felt a little slow but the topics themselves  particularly the assigned readings  were very interesting.
A strength is the accessibility of Professor Zang and the TAs.

Strengths: responsive TAs, interesting readings, engaging discussions
Weaknesses: Lack of information about expectations for the course, sometimes disengaging lectures

The textbook is incredibly outdated and overtly racist/prejudiced in many different ways. We didn't use it that much, and we didn't really talk about its biases in class. 
Class work was really fast-paced and we covered a lot of topics in demography without a high degree of specificity/elaboration. It just ended up being mostly memorization (esp. for the calculations).

Strengths: Even though the class was a lecture, it felt more like a seminar. During lecture, Professor Zang asked questions and students answered, and Professor Zang always periodically paused to ask if anyone had questions. The workload wasn't bad and exams weren't graded harshly. Professor Zang is probably the course's biggest asset. She's super approachable and understanding, always has a great attitude, and is willing to accommodate students to make sure they succeed and truly understand the material.
Weaknesses: Watch out for the 20 page final paper. Not that it's a necessarily difficult assignment, but 20 pages can be a real headache around finals time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were not recorded until about a month or so in; recording from the start would have been helpful, especially for exam review. A longer window to submit the exam without penalty would be better as well.
The discussion section was very helpful. It was also helpful that exams were open notebook.

the discussion format is effective in engaging the entire class. Could be made better if the final presentations have more interactive elements so that the audience can engage more with each other's presentation
Communication could be improved a little bit - getting situated in a section and what subjects or lessons we are about to go into.
I thought the format worked well overall. I think more strategies could have been employed to keep us engaged during lecture.
I don't think we needed to have as many readings as we did, especially since the lectures basically covered the exact same content as the readings.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they are looking for not explicitly science focused sci credit yes, and also if they have general interest in studying people/population, then yes
Yes because the course material throughout the course is very interesting and you will learn a lot, but the choice of a Final Project needs improvement.
Yes, for any students interested in social science and learning about population trends

Yes - this course is relatively introductory but it covers the key topics including the demographic transition. After this class, you will better understand news report about population growth, age structure, mortality, and more.
Yes, it was interesting to see how off I would predict some statistics of the US (ex. population growth, causes of death, average age of fertility)
Yes. It was a good way to get a science credit for non-STEM students. I was always very interested in the discussions we were having, and I felt that the professor was really looking out for us.

Not at the moment. This is a newer course, so they might change it next year, but if you're looking for an intro to the sociology department at Yale there are better and honestly more interesting courses to take.
Yes! Gut science credit.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The live lecture was very interactive and Professor Zang gave us many opportunities to speak by asking questions. We also had a weekly discussion section.
& virtual discussion section
Live virtual lecture + live virtual discussion section
Discussion section and some recorded lectures
weekly section to supplement the lectures
virtual lecture/seminar
Two virtual 50min classes per week- one lecture and one discussion section. This is a lecture class but made up of several small sections.
In addition, there was a virtual section!
Live virtual lecture + live virtual discussion section
